Yes, Ma'am, I think so. Mavis echoes Agnis' glare. QUOYLE (really casual)
Macau, huh? So. That where y'sent th' chairs? Agnis turns.   Sizes him up. AGNIS

It's flatterin' you showin' me how you've turned into such a competent reporter and all. But even if I remembered where I sent 'em. I couldn't tell ya. Puts her fingers to her lips.      Leans closer, to confi he is obviously unaware of... AGNIS
Professional ethics.
CLOSE on Wavey, cooking flapjacks.      Talking to them. WAVEY
Only you.     Could do this. And she's not pleased. WAVEY You fed him. You gave him clothes. You're the first human ever was kind to him...
She scoops them expertly into a stack. WAVEY Accordingly. You're sick with guilt.
Serves them to... WAVEY You sure you're not a complex guy?

...Quoyle, who nods absently. About the one thing he is s Just now, he's examining the prodigious status of her oxb knitting. Still attached to the needles, it looks too bro a muffler. QUOYLE (decides) Horse blanket. WAVEY (ah!) That's what that is!
A beat.   Another. QUOYLE So if y'called around.      Musta found somepla... WAVEY (quietly) One decent golden age home. It's in St. John's. You can maybe afford it, tho God knows why you should.
She pushes the flapjacks closer to him, CLANKS down the f She's exasperated. Thinks he's wasting his money. QUOYLE I can't put him there, til I go down to St. John's. See it's all right.
Great!      Let's not be rash! QUOYLE Come with me.
And everything.      Sorta.    Stops. QUOYLE I mean, the kids could stay with
Dennis and Beety.       Or Agnis, or... A meaningful beat. WAVEY
Why.   Would I. Do that? She looks deep in his eyes. Hard to guess the answer she hear. He clears his throat. Looks down. QUOYLE
Well. Remember when you said. Someday, I'd do something nice for you? And when he looks to her, she is... PETAL (Wavey's voice)
And this is it. A witheringly sexy smile. QUOYLE
Hey. Overnight trip to St. John's. All expenses paid. Petal arches a delicate brow. PETAL (Wavey's voice)
Overnight? He blinks.   And sees... WAVEY
What's wrong with a weekend? With a playful smile.      Of her own.
Not London, but it might as well be. Wavey and Quoyle ato double-decker bus, wind whipping their hair. She is watch big city flow past, drinking every inch of it. He's watch

Wavey carries an armload of little girl's tights and cord pants, picking through a bin of barrettes. Quoyle appears fistful of neckties. Holds them up hopefully to his chest time, each more breathtakingly godawful than the last. We SHIVERS with disgust. Lifts from her shopping bag a nice vative one she's already picked for him. He SHIVERS, just did. They share the trace of a grin, just alike. He walks ...Wavey trying on furry hats in a full-length mirror, as keeps feeding her an endless supply from a double armful. pouts and poses like a runway model, basically frowning t hats aren't working. He's staring at her as if nothing el in the universe. She knows it. ...Wavey alone at a cash register. The checker is ringing selection of lacy bras and panties. Suddenly, Wavey looks see Quoyle at the register one aisle over, staring fixedl purchases. Seeing she's noticed him, he holds up a huge p loud boxer shorts he's buying, and WAVES them at her. She and waves her bras right back. Civilians watching think t in love.

...Quoyle and Wavey stroll the grounds of Nolan's future home. It is twilight, and the modest place looks pleasant welcoming. Quoyle listens earnestly, as the director poin out. Wavey watching Quoyle, her gaze not so disapproving all. ...CLOSE on Quoyle with a bowling ball, poised, glaring o Here he comes. Stumbles. Lets go. REVERSE ANGLE to see th rolling, rolling real slow. Quoyle turns his back, stride with confidence like he doesn't even have to watch, this easy. Wavey points, look. He turns in time to see two pin Pumps his fist. YESSSS!

It's late. It's dim. It's as romantic as urban Newfoundla ever get. Our couple nursing beers at the corner table of passably stylish bar. Piano playing show tunes, but soft. pulls from his pocket... ...a travel brochure.     Slightly drunk, completely merr wicked smile. QUOYLE Now, listen to this for t'morrow. After I sign the papers at the home...

She's already grinning.     Feels so comfortable. QUOYLE (reads) The answer to your annual outing! Rainbow trout fishing in four ponds. You pay for what you catch. Prizes in the ponds. If it drizzles or gets chilly, heated and lighted building available, right next to the ponds, with soft drinks, candy bars, ice cream and chips!
His subtle smile.     A guy could get used to this irony WAVEY Or we could sleep in.
...innocent, natural.       At some primal level, his pan WAVEY I just feel so guilty about all your expenses. Two separate rooms. Both so big. QUOYLE Hey, it's my treat.     You agreed.
She nods.    She did. WAVEY Still. Seems like we could figure out. Something.
Even Quoyle. Has the message. He looks down at his beer, thinks about what he should say. Turns the glass in his f QUOYLE A friend told me once. Love is the only thing that counts.
He nods.    Almost to himself. QUOYLE (a murmur) It's the engine of life.

He looks up.    Her eyes are waiting. QUOYLE So when you told me how you think about your husband. I really understood, becau... WAVEY That's what I wanted us to talk abou... QUOYLE ...because real love.     Just comes once.
And everything.    Stops. QUOYLE See, you know some of the stories about Petal. Some of the bad things. What you don't know...
But she's looking in his eyes.       And so, she does. WAVEY (just above a whisper) ...is how much you love her.
That's what it is.
Even tho.    She never loved you.
A beat.
Sorta.    Because of it.
He sighs. The most miserable and the most honest he has e All at once. QUOYLE See, love. Isn't about what's good for you. Isn't about what you wish it was. Isn't about what...would make you happy.
His eyes are swimming.       Can she possibly hear this? QUOYLE Love. Is about want. What you really want. And you can't change that. Even if it's poison.
Silence.   The piano plays something gay and stupid. QUOYLE So that's why it's great. To have a real friend. When you're. Lonely.
The last word was a tough one.       It makes her nod. Sh his eyes for the longest time.       And when she speaks, hear her voice... WAVEY I know you have to stay tomorrow. To sign the papers. But.
But.   One word.    And even a stupid guy.    Gets it all WAVEY I should be heading back. Before Herry. Misses me. Too much.
Wow. He nods, dumbly.        Watching his worst nightmare his eyes. WAVEY And I'm not feeling so well. What I get for mixing vodka and beer, huh.
She gets to her feet.       She does seem a little unstea WAVEY So I'll grab a taxi. You stay and finish. Listen to the music. Is that all right? QUOYLE I cou...
But he stops.     Because she's shaken her head once. WAVEY And don't worry.     I'm still your friend.

Her voice chokes a little on that.        She shakes her grinning at how foolish she feels.        She smiles at h she means it. And leaves.     Without another word. QUOYLE (V.O.) She did stay my friend. In her way. Even tho, for awhile, we didn't see each other a lot.
He wants to cry. He wants to be sick. He doesn't know wha wants. Fumbles in his pocket for some wadded-up bills. QUOYLE (V.O.) Funny. How one little talk.      Can change everything.
The boys, the beers, the squidburgers.        The usual. QUOYLE Tell me about it. Just get the aunt's house fixed perfect, and I gotta move.

Move? QUOYLE Three hours to drive from the Point, with all the ice. Alvin won't have my boat ready til New Years. Agnis can stay over her shop. Bunny and I have to find a room in town. DENNIS Stay with us. My kid follows yours around, they'll bunk t'gether. And we gotta fluffy couch that's more'n you deserve.
A good friend.     Quoyle is touched. QUOYLE Hopin' you'd offer, almost worth it just t'inconvenience ya. Unfortunately, I'm too fond a yer wife. NUTBEEM (casual) Take my trailer. Timing's perfect.
The way he said that.     They both turn.     A shrug... NUTBEEM It's two years. My boat's ready. If I stay any longer, I'll begin to like it here.
Wouldn't want that. Very silent at this table. the place. Is he serious? NUTBEEM (softly) I'm throwing myself a farewell party on Saturday. Departure to follow Sunday. Regrets, soon after, no doubt.
And smiles.    Serious as a heart attack.      A long bea QUOYLE (a murmur) Be careful.
Careful? QUOYLE Last friend left me.      Turned into a truck driver.
So much feeling behind his eyes.     Nutbeem can only say NUTBEEM Well.   With that warning.
And return the feeling.     With his own.

Quoyle GROANING under the weight of cases of beer and che pulled from the back of his wagon. Plenty more to go. Sta into... ...Nutbeem's   tiny, threadbare trailer. Every conceivabl under stacks   of plastic-wrapped party platters of cold and red-eyed   olives. Nutbeem is jamming beers into tubs Quoyle peers   into the teensy closet that is the only ba QUOYLE What's the barrel for?
SEE it now.    Half a sawed-off empty BARREL, with MOLASS in orange, fills the shower stall. NUTBEEM
I'm British. I bathe. Quoyle sends him a blank look. QUOYLE
Perfect for th' chips. He gestures to thirty bags of potato chips, filling the kitchenette. NUTBEEM
It's coated with two kinds of scum. Soap. And mine. QUOYLE
Works.    We forgot to buy dip.

VIEW out a window at the line of HEADLIGHTS still arrivin immersed in the ungodly WHITE NOISE of an all-gentleman's soiree, music pushed beyond the level of distortion, asso grunts, squeals, unintelligible words, things breaking. A struggle to look around... ...every square inch is    crammed tight with semi-consci Tert Card and some boys    circle the potato chip barrel, become a handy urinal.     Near the door, Dennis holding tight around Quoyle who    listens, listens, chuckles. Th fights his way... ...OUT of the trailer, to cold night air where the party wilder, given the elbow room. Quoyle steps OVER the supin Billy Pretty, who is singing to himself. Finds Jack Buggi beer in one hand a rum in the other. Wraps a drunken arm Jack's neck. Starts to talk in his ear. Jack looks suspic FIGHT breaks out a few feet away. They don't notice. Clos to hear... QUOYLE (shouting against the din)

head_text.subj: SO THE NEXT DAY, THEY ALL SIT DOWN
ON THE GIRDER. THE BRIT OPENS HIS
JUMPS OFF THE GIRDER TO HIS DEATH.

text: Jack nods.   Grins.    That's pretty funny. QUOYLE

head_text.subj: THE QUEBEC GUY OPENS HIS LUNCH BOX.

text: This.   Is even funnier. QUOYLE

head_text.subj: NOW THE STATIE IS ALL ALONE ON
THE GIRDER. HE OPENS HIS BOX.

text: Funniest yet.   Jack is chuckling already. QUOYLE

head_text.subj: AT THE FUNERAL. THE BRIT' S WIFE
SAYS, 'WHY DIDN'T HE TELL ME HE HATED
DIDN'T HE COMPLAIN ABOUT THE MEAT
GET IT. HE ALWAYS MADE HIS OWN LUNCH

text: Quoyle is chortling.   But Jack stares him dead in the ey JACK

head_text.subj: YOU'RE SURE. THE FELLER WAS A STATIE.

text: QUOYLE
At which point Jack BUSTS OUT laughing fit to wet his pan JACK

POUNDING on poor Quoyle, who is also dissolved in hysteri Nearby, the biggest and ugliest GUY at the party (no smal distinction) leaps onto a tree stump brandishing an AXE. Even in this crowd, it commands a certain degree of atten BIG UGLY GUY

head_text.subj: NOW WE ALL LOVES OLD FOOKIN' NUTBEEM,

text: Cries of YAR! fill the woods. Nutbeem himself is HOISTED shoulders, whooping and sloshing his grog. BIG UGLY GUY

An idea that wins IMMEDIATE MASS APPROVAL. Soused Nutbeem open bug-wide, as he is borne in a tidal wave of mayhem t docks. Whatever he is shrieking may well prove ineffectiv And rather suddenly.   Quoyle is left alone. Among the conscious, that is.

Knitted wool, the color of oxblood, lies across a timewor ottoman. In front of it, little Herry dances a shuffle-fo his own design. The music seeps from a venerable accordia earnestly by his serious mom, nodding and tapping her foo time of his steps. There is a feeling of empowerment and release in Herry. H splits his round face. His eyes say that his heart is dan PULL SLOWLY BACK...through the window, past the porch, ac front yard. To a figure. By the fence. He stands motionle Except his foot is tapping, very slightly, to the time of music. We can't tell how much Quoyle sees.    But his eyes say t heart is drowning.

As Quoyle shuffles up, we see Nutbeem's trailer has been completely OVER onto its side. Walls are crushed and spli It's a train wreck. Sitting on the cinder blocks that once supported it, Nutb and Dennis swig beers. NUTBEEM (cheery)
You're looking dishy, Q. QUOYLE
Feeling that and more.    What's the situation? Nutbeem hands him a beer. NUTBEEM
One. You're moving in with Dennis, no matter how fond you are of his wife. Quoyle looks sadly at the trailer.    Realizing it was hi got trashed. NUTBEEM (laughs)
And the boat! Omigod! BILLY
I'm some disgusted.    With the human race. NUTBEEM

I'da never made it, anyway. Storms would have blown me to bits. You boys saved my life. Yes, you did. The boys look at each other.    Humiliated by his generos NUTBEEM I've gathered my savings, and am flying to Brazil. Where water is swimming pool green. And I grill yellowtail steaks with lime and garlic, watercress and Tobasco. Touch of curry. What?
Quoyle is looking at him somewhat strangely. QUOYLE (light) I collect friends who cook.     Just can't keep 'em.
Maybe too light not to be obvious.     Billy looks from Q trailer. And back. BILLY It's too bad.
Which seems to cover everything.

Quoyle alone with Jack in open water. Pulling on a slicke gloves, picking up a knife. Jack is pronging cod onto the JACK Hands might as well be movin' while we chat. Always hated th' sight a grown men around a table workin' nuthin' but their jaws.
And so, together, they begin to clean a small mountain of QUOYLE Editorial meetin', y'say.     'Bout what? JACK Well, Tert Card's gone, fer one thing.
Doesn't look up. JACK Yar, I know, he never said g'bye. Well, don't get all weepy-eyed about it, old son. Try t'be a man.
Quoyle will. JACK They called him from St. John's, he tells me. Wants him to help put out th' newsletter fer them oil rig suppliers.

Yup.     Believe it. JACK He was sassy an' he was smug. Oh, there's a waitin' list, he assures me. They only skims th' cream. QUOYLE Well, don't get all weepy-eyed abou... JACK Truth t'tell. I was a wee help. B'hind the scenes, doncha know.
Keeps working. JACK (quietly) Sometimes.     Enough is enough.

No arguments arise. QUOYLE Well, Billy'll do a helluva job... JACK (nods) ...right where he is. Too old a fish t'swim faster'n be wants. Gotta find someone a little dumber t'take on a shit job like this!
Uh-oh.     You don't mean... JACK Spot I'm in, Christmas and all. Might have to offer th'mess. To you.
Quoyle swallows.       Arguably the proudest moment of hi
Course.     I'd need a raise.
Jack looks at him for the first time.        A real twink JACK Y'know. Yer do have the sense God gave a doughnut. QUOYLE (genuinely touched) I'II try to live up to that.
Said with such sincerity, Jack can only nod.          Goo JACK Any other outrageous demands? Seein' as yer got me over a barrel. Here's your one chance.
And before he can stop his mouth... QUOYLE Well, your son...
The mirth dies in his host's eyes. Like a 60-watt bulb in brownout. Quoyle swallows the rest. JACK You were sayin'...?
Quoyle sucks it up. QUOYLE His whole life would be changed. If he could come upon. A fishing license.
Jack's eyes.   Flat and cold as the cod he's gutting. JACK Well, there's only one a those issued per family. So how exactly would he do that?
This is not.   Going well.   A dangerous silence. JACK Even doughnuts, y'know.   Can push their luck.

The day care contingent more organized today. Sort of. Bu leading a spirited round of red-light/green-light, as... ...Quoyle enters with a big cardboard box full of present shrugs off his coat, he looks at the Christmas tree, its lights. The decorations that seem to be everywhere, many by these children. He watches Bunny call out 'Red Light!' have Herry ignore it and tackle her anyway. Mixed emotions, to be sure. A feeling of family he can at visit, yet will never be his own. The sad edge catches up him, so he strolls on into... ...the kitchen. Wavey baking, what else.      She smiles A friend's smile. WAVEY (Southern belle) Why, Mistuh Quoyle. You shouldn't have!
He smiles back.    Takes her in for a telling beat, befor QUOYLE Uh.   I didn't. Most of these
are for Herry. Even better. QUOYLE
There's two. Are yours. They are on top. Personally wrapped in his slightly bulgi fine-motor-control-challenged, personal style. Be sets th counter. QUOYLE
You prob'ly want to wait for Christmas. Meaning, please don't. So she wipes her hands on her apro him see her eyes dance just a flicker. WAVEY

Oh, I'm much too excited. Delicately unwraps the first. Lifts out a PORCELAIN TEAPO painted with an assortment of BERRIES. She holds it in he at once admiring and wistful. Wondering if there's a mess their moment together while berry-picking. QUOYLE
It's from a museum catalogue.       But it's not real. It's a copy. WAVEY (still gazing at it)
It is my favorite teapot. A simple pronouncement. She opens the second, flat and na is a TURQUOISE BRACELET. Actually, kind of stunning. She taken back by the beauty and perhaps the expense. QUOYLE
It's nice for your eyes.     I thought. She doesn't sayanything.   Lets it dangle from her finger the light. QUOYLE
It's for everyday. You don't have to save it for special. She looks to him. Her eyes are shining maybe more than sh Her voice perhaps softer than she even intends... WAVEY
Oh, I'll save this, all right. Covers.   With only a slightly more than friendly smile. WAVEY

And I'll think of you.     When I put lot on. He can only nod. He'd like that.    She holds up one fing second. And hurries off. So he waits. Looking at her kitchen. Feeling his feelings is back, with two boxes. Sets them down. Nods, go ahead.. ...one is heavy and square. He opens it to find a LEATHER CASE. He looks at her, smiles in his childlike way. Opens case, which reveals... ...two leather-bound VOLUMES. One a dictionary.      The thesaurus. He is obviously moved. QUOYLE (a murmur)
You must have me mistaken. For a writer. And when he looks up. WAVEY

I don't make mistakes.     About that kind of thing. He stares at her long enough to make her nod toward the o package. Big and flat, but not heavy at all. He lifts the and pulls out... ...a huge comfy SWEATER.   In oxblood wool.    He is comp stunned to realize... WAVEY (so pleased)
Well, you can't be surprised. You've seen me knitting it for months. QUOYLE

It was so big, I thought it was a tea cozy for your car. But if it's for me, it has to be bigger, huh? Put it on, put it on! So he slips it over his head. Big e and then some. This worries her. She plucks at it... WAVEY
Well.   You'll grow into it. QUOYLE
You kiddin'? After the holidays, we'll have to stretch it. He's just beaming. Hugs himself to show how warm it is. silence is companionable. Then... QUOYLE

Not used to a woman.     Giving me presents. She raises a brow.     Can scarcely believe that. QUOYLE One Christmas with Petal, I gave her eleven things. And I wrapped them. And watched her open them up.
She holds her friendly smile.     But her eyes have chang Slightly. QUOYLE She didn't have anything for me. Like every year. But this one time, she said, 'Wait a minute.'
Wait a minute. QUOYLE She ran to the kitchen. I heard the fridge open. She came back. With her hands hidden behind her. Then, she held out...
Even his voice.    Betrays the longing. QUOYLE Two brown eggs. She gave them to me from her own hands. They were cold.
He smiles, self-conscious. QUOYLE Must sound really stupid.   But they meant a lot to me.
Silence.   A soft... WAVEY Well.   It's the thought that counts.
He nods.   He's glad she understands. QUOYLE I broke 'em, careful. Made her an omelette with 'em. And I saved the shells. In a little box.
She can't help but show her surprise at that. QUOYLE Oh, yeh. They're on a shelf behind my desk. At the paper.
He looks worried now.     Shouldn't have brought this up. this... WAVEY I know how it is. To hold onto something good. In the middle of all the bad.
He nods.     But feels truly awkward now.     So... QUOYLE Well. I gotta collect Bunny. Beety's gonna have supper waiting.
Right.     She nods.   She understands this, too.
Thank you.     Thank you, very much.
Takes her teapot and her bracelet.        Holds them. Her hands now too full for a hug. QUOYLE Well.   Merry Christmas!
With a wonderful smile. WAVEY Merry Christmas.
With one of her own.

Quoyle enters a packed auditorium, festooned for Christ's with every trimming imaginable. Rough fishermen in black they wear once a year, women in finery, schoolkids at the scrubbed best, antsy with anticipation. The BUZZ is audib palpable. No Broadway opening could hope for this level o eagerness. As Quoyle comes down the aisle, we see faces we know. Boy Nutbeem's party. Billy Pretty with Jack and Mrs. Buggit. Yark and his bird-like wife. The old-timer who sold Quoyl boat. Mavis Bangs with an empty seat next to her, must be for Agnis. All the kids from daycare. Still, Quoyle searc the face he doesn't find. And finally... ...to the third row, where Dennis and Beety have saved hi Beety gives him a peck on the cheek, and he smiles, settl nervous as hell, just as... ...the school principal, still dressed for England, walks mike at center stage. Holds up her hands like the discipl she prides herself on being, and they quiet pretty fast. PRINCIPAL Your friends and neighbors, and most of all, your children. Have
worked hard to bring you the best pageant ever. THUNDEROUS applause, whistling, stamping. She is frustrat moment. Then, waves cheerily against the din, shouting... PRINCIPAL

And RUNS off-stage, as we DISSOLVE THROUGH a SERIES OF AN ...the Big Ugly Guy who led the raid on poor Nutbeem's bo in a threadworn suit bulging with his bulk, singing DANNY the sweetest tenor one could dream of. PAN an audience, r motionless. Pavarotti never had more respect. ...Bunny and Marty walk timidly to the front of the stage dressed in Christmas reds and greens. Bunny all in blue, does look good on her. Kids CALL OUT their names. The pla quiet. And the girls begin to sing a plaintive West Afric in small brave voices that sometimes harmonize. It is une and breathtakingly courageous. Two dads in the third row tears flooding their eyes... DENNIS (gruff whisper)
Not bad, my kid, eh? QUOYLE (gruffer whisper)

I'll say.    She's as good as mine. ...Agnis Hamm walks out alone onto the stage, wearing a b jersey, tweed skirt, yellow stockings and red slippers. S an odd look on her face, all serious and curious. The lau calls die away to silence. Suddenly, one of her feet SCRA the stage, her arms become WINGS, and with a CROONING and she metamorphoses into a PEEVISH HEN protecting an egg. T comes DOWN with laughter and UNISON applause. Quoyle glan at Mavis Bangs who puts her fingers between her teeth and in pure delight. ...Wavey Prowse walks onto the rear of the stage, in a lo smock, carrying her accordion. She turns to the wings, no out comes little Herry clacking across the stage in tap s beat of silence. Mom calls out: ONE, TWO, THREE, rolls in savage hornpipe and Herry commences the JIG Quoyle once g through a window. Three hundred HEELS coming STOMPING dow perfect rhythm and lift Herry into a joyous bouncing, rat performance that builds in intensity until the finish. He to the edge of the stage, bows DEEP from the waist, stand in their applause. Then RACES offstage, his mom following dignity, and we go with her into the wings... Once there, Wavey slips OUT of the smock, revealing to th of the wings, that she is wearing dancer's tights over dr legs. A close-fitting tunic covered with sequins and glas crystal diamonds, and dozens more glittering baubles that shimmer of prisms with her every breath. Herry hands her hat, a cane, and... ...she STALKS back onto the stage, her lithe body strutti glinting. A hush of stupefaction falls, only to be washed by SHOUTS and WHISTLES, the kind of which have not been h since Gypsy Rose Lee startled her first roomful of rubes. the bedlam... ...she TWIRLS the top hat on one finger, FLIPS it up in a somersault, catching it square on her head. She leans on And when at last they quiet... WAVEY
We all know Billy Pretty's ways. Never save fifty cents, if you can save a dollar. She winks.   They laugh.   Billy laughing loudest. WAVEY

Well, last Feb'ry, Billy wants t'get his grandfather clock repaired. Calls old Leander Mesher. Local call. No charge. Twirls the cane recklessly.    In the third row, a goggle couldn't blink if he tried. WAVEY
Well, says Leander, the big cost is pickup and delivery. Got t'charge fifty dollars, each way. Two strong boys. Gasoline. Air in the tires! That's right. WAVEY
There's no cost for air in yer tires!, says Bill. Get wi' th'times, he's told. Tis called inflation! WAGGLES her eyebrows, Groucho-style.    They are busting laughing. Connoisseurs of wit. WAVEY

Billy lives at the top of the hill, Leander at the bot tom, doncha know. So Billy gets a rope, HOISTS the grandfather UP on his back. And muttering the words fifty bucks... She puts her toe out, SLIPS wildly, windmilling her arms, pantomiming as she bends double under the phantom clock. WAVEY
Mite slick. Four feet thick a ice. Tears are streaming from a hundred eyes and more. WAVEY

Meanwhile, at the bottom, Auntie Fizzard, 91 years young, sets out in her non-slip galoshes and her cane with the rubber tip. Didn't yer, dearie? Bows to the old gal in the front row, who is scarlet-face hysterics, as all around her applaud. Wavey becomes her, along, casting fierce glances right and left to warn the WAVEY

Meanwhile, at the top... She is Billy once more, beneath his burden, her long legs stepping to one side, then the other, slipping, skidding, howling all around her threatening to shatter walls, and. WAVEY
...OVER he goes, clock-side down, and PICKIN' UP SPEED! Miming the wild ride as they ROAR... WAVEY
...eight blocks, NINE, missing everything like a miracle, zeroing in on... She becomes Auntie Fizzard once more, shuffling, looking right, and suddenly up WILD-EYED! WAVEY
CLIPS 'er inta the snow bank! Nods sadly.   Leaning on her cane.     When at last they WAVEY
Just two galoshes stickin' outta the snow. She digs 'er way out. Brushes herself off. Looks at him sprawled like a turtle on his back, tied to his massive burden. She says... She says. WAVEY
Levels a dead-eyed killer gaze. WAVEY

head_text.subj: WHY CAN'T YOU WEAR A WRISTWATCH

text: The place comes DOWN like a house of cards. Bedlam surrou Quoyle who sits still as a stone. Too dazzled to breathe. EXT. ROADSIDE DINER - EARLY MORNING. Lonely stretch of wooded road, middle of nowhere. Light s starting to fall. A truck pulls up beneath a tree. Out cl ...Wavey. Looking grim, walking slow. Crosses the road to weathered diner. The woman who only smokes when she's wor pulls out a pack of Camels. Looks through the diner's fro window... ...a lone customer sits nursing his coffee. He is 40, lea attractive. Dark hard eyes, set into worries of their own lights up. Watches in silence until... ...the man looks up. Their eyes meet through the glass. And on his faint smile... She turns her back.   Starts up the road. ANGLE...he is walking beside her now. Snow drifting lazy, smoke curling up. He watches her anger, how cold and quie closed. Smiles at her profile... HEROLD
I shoulda come last night.     Seen the show. She can't even believe he said that.     Never looking at WAVEY
Woulda been a thrill for the Christians among' em. They think you're dead. Keep walking.   His smile is gentle. HEROLD
Well, then we got good news for th... WAVEY
So does your son. A beat. HEROLD
Even better news for him. WAVEY (low)
You think so. Breaking the words off.   He's watching her profile. HEROLD (very soft)
I can't undo the hurt I've done. Unless you let me. Gauging the feeling behind the bitterness. HEROLD
There's a million reasons to send me away. Good ones. And only two reasons not to. Is she even listening?     He lets the silence hang. HEROLD
I love you. And you love me. She stops walking.     Flips her cigarette off into the s now... Looks into his face.     And sighs.

Rear ANGLE of Agnis, crouching in the lightly falling sno edge of the sea. The spot where she once sent her dog to HEAR footfalls crunching slowly across the rocks. A bulky comes into frame. Crouches down beside her. Close. She st the gray horizon. QUOYLE (softly)
Mavis Bangs. Told me where you'd be. No answer.   But she hears him all right. QUOYLE
We get so little mention in the wires. Thought you'd like to see. He hands the folded print-out to her. QUOYLE
Head in the suitcase.       The mystery's solved. She looks briefly at his eyes.        Takes it.   Starts QUOYLE
Silver Melville was captured in Moored with a cruise steward. The boy was twenty, a looker, wearing Armani clothes. Driving a nice Lexus. Agnis keeps reading. QUOYLE

Says she did it all for love. She nods at that.      Folds the paper neatly, as if conv Hands it back. AGNIS She'd call me, time to time. Husband was a pig. More women should do what she done. Her situation.
He looks in her eyes.      And decides to say... QUOYLE Some women. Shoulda done it to their brother.
The look holds.      She sees the compassion in his eyes. so on her side.      She clears her throat. AGNIS (softly) Cousin Nolan. Hafta pay him a visit.
They share a look.      He glances at the sea.        Bea QUOYLE Mavis said you buried Warren here. Called it an anniversary.
She stares deep and unblinking into his eyes.
Of a loss.     But not the dog.
A held moment. AGNIS What makes us do that, nephew? Give ourselves away to someone. So we can't eat or think or breathe without 'em? QUOYLE (just above a whisper) I don't know. We just do.
Silence.   And... AGNIS Wonderful, ain't it?
And now she smiles.      Something we have rarely seen. AGNIS Irene Warren died. The mornin' after a Christmas. We get one true love in life, nephew. She was mine.
He's not surprised.     And that, in turn, does not reall her. AGNIS
Don't mean we can't give love again. And get some back. QUOYLE
For some, it does. AGNIS (straight back)
Not for me. Strong with that.     Sure. AGNIS
And if that ruffles some small town feathers... His smile in return.     Very real. QUOYLE
Y'know what the feathers around here need th' most? A good ruffling, I say. He sounds pretty sure himself.         Their look ho1ds. QUOYLE
Y'know what I need th' most? She doesn't. QUOYLE
A really big breakfast! She nods, one last time.      Sounds like a plan.

Quoyle alone with his cut-and-paste, making up the front layout. Moonlight on fallen snow through the window. Late quiet enough, to hear... ...the vehicle drive up, the engine turn off. The footfal door, which swings open. The last person he'd expect to s Especially with a bottle. Of Cuervo Gold. They stare at each other.      Only he smiles. QUOYLE
Hey.     Congratulations. She shoots him a quizzical look.         We see the edge if he doesn't. QUOYLE
Last night.     On the stage?    You were... Shakes his head with innocent admiration.       She puts his desk. WAVEY
It was easy. I just kept thinkin'. How would Petal do it? He hears it now, right enough. The anger, the Cuervo. She on over to the coffee counter, only a bit wobbly. Plucks styrofoam cups. WAVEY
We're friends, right?     Friends drink together. Back to his desk. Shrugs her coat off onto the floor. Pul and jeans, she looks terrific. Hikes her butt up onto the his desk. WAVEY
I asked a quest... QUOYLE (quiet)
I'll drink with you. If you're not done yet. Her soft throaty laugh. He hasn't seen her this way. if it's more scary or exciting. WAVEY
Not drunk enough yet to talk about Petal. Which we always seem to do. Opens the bottle.   About four fingers are gone. WAVEY
